*** Bug 91413 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

This is all very disconcerting.

Tom, can you confirm Rafael's claim in bug 91413, that this NPE could only 
occur if the bundle description is not in the state?

It seems like PDE is calling getFragments before adding the BundleDescription 
to the state.  I will try to confirm this.

I have the following projects from CVS HEAD extracted in my workspace:

org.eclipse.core.runtime
org.eclipse.jface
org.eclipse.osgi
org.eclipse.swt
org.eclipse.swt.win32.win32.x86
org.eclipse.ui.workbench

Then I used the steps to reproduce but it worked for me.  Am I missing a 
project?

I actually have a lot of other projects in my worskpace, not all from
dev.eclipse.org.  I also forgot that I had previously removed the SWT projects
due the fragment change.
I'll try reproducing it in a fresh workspace containing my usual self-hosting setup.

Wassim, if State#updateBundle is called with a bundle that has a bundle ID not 
already in the state then we will return without adding the bundle to the 
state.  This is one way we could get into this situation.  Is it possible that 
you are calling PDEState#addBundle(Dictionary, File, boolean, long) with a non-
negative bundleId which does not exist in the state.

If this is true, one possible fix would be to have State#updateBundle add the 
BundleDescription when the bundleId does not already exist in the State.  This 
would be equivalent to calling State#addBundle.

I still have not been able to reproduce the error.

One thing I'm afraid of is the possibility that the classpath update might 
take place before the state has been resolved.  I'll investigate.

Re: comment 10

Not resolving the state first would not cause the NPE to occur.  It would 
cause the getFragments call to return an empty array.  To get the correct 
results you should first resolve the state, but I do not think that is the 
cause of this bug.

I wasn't able to reproduce it in a fresh workspace either.
I had the following loaded, and a few external plug-ins added to the Java search
path (via the Plug-ins view):

org.eclipse.core.commands
org.eclipse.core.filebuffers
org.eclipse.core.resources
org.eclipse.core.runtime
org.eclipse.jface
org.eclipse.jface.text
org.eclipse.osgi

I can no longer reproduce it in my original workspace either.
I tried closing some of the non-eclipse projects, tried the change, and there
were no problems.  I then reopened those projects, tried the change again, and
still no problem.

I had to restart this worskpace earlier to recover from the original problem, so
I guess that forced a re-computation of the classpaths and cleaned up whatever
fragile state it was in before.

considering that it fails when looking for fragments, then we can narrow it 
down to bundles that have Eclipse-ExtensibleAPI set to true.

So now we're down to 2 bundles: org.eclipse.osgi and org.eclipse.swt

I double-checked that updating a classpath is never invoked before PDE had a 
chance to update the state.

So it might be that the updateBundle is failing, so I now "add" the bundle to 
the state if the update failed.

since an NPE during the pde container resolution is the worst possible thing 
that could happen during development, I added an extra paranoic safety measure 
to check if bundleDescription.getContainingState is not null before we query 
the state for its fragments.

I suspect bug 91513 may be related to this.

Nick, around the time this happened, did you happen to press the 'Validate 
Plugin Set' button on the Plugins tab?

Quite possibly.  I've been using the fine 'Validate Plugin Set' action a fair
bit lately.  I feel so much more secure now knowing that PDE is being extra
paranoid for me.

Should BundleDescriptionImpl#getFragments be paranoid as well?  Seems like it 
should throw an IllegalStateException instead, but I'm not a fan of replacing 
one runtime exception with another.

Another option is to return an empty array if the containing state is null.  
This would completely mask the problem and we would never have known one 
existed, so I don't think that is a good option either.

The only difference is that an NPE looks like the called code has a bug.  
IllegalState implies that somehow the caller or the system is at fault.  You 
can also convey more information (e.g., "the state is ...").

In any event, these seem like micro points.  We can hide the problem (return 
empty array) if the situation really doesn't matter and we really don't expect 
it to happen

I am a big fan of tough love.  Please leave the runtime code as-is.  It would 
point out potential mismanagment of the state by PDE, rahter than hide it.
